required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Rotator Cuff Tears in Hemiplegic Shoulder
clinical_study.official_title: Observational Study to Evaluate the Prevalence of Rotator Cuff Tears in Hemiplegic Shoulders

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to evaluate the prevalence of rotator cuff tears in the shoulders of hemiplegic patients of different severity.

detailed_description.textblock: Rotator cuff tears are often suspected to contribute hemiplegic shoulder pain. However, it is controversial whether their incidence increases in hemiplegia. Based on the postulate that muscle weakness in hemiplegia predisposes rotator cuff injury due to biomechanical failure, this study aims to investigate whether the rotator cuff tears are associated with the muscle strength of the shoulder by observing hemiplegic shoulders of varying degree of paresis.

primary_outcome.measure: Rotator Cuff Tear of the Hemiplegic Shoulder, Confirmed by Ultrasonography
primary_outcome.description: All patients underwent ultrasonography (USG) for the both, affected and unaffected, shoulders. USG routinely examined biceps, subscapularis, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus tendons as for the partial or complete tears, calcifications, bony irregularity and bursal swellings.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rotator Cuff Tear of the Unaffected Shoulder, Confirmed by Ultrasonography
secondary_outcome.description: All patients were performed ultrasonography (USG) for the both, affected and unaffected, shoulders. USG routinely examined biceps, subscapularis, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus tendons as for the partial or complete tears, calcifications, bony irregularity and bursal swellings.

secondary_outcome.measure: Subluxation of the Glenohumeral Joint, Confirmed by Physical Examination
secondary_outcome.description: The glenohumeral joint subluxation was examined by palpating the subacromial regions of the both sides and comparing the affected side with the unaffected side while patients are seated and relaxed. If the palpated space between the acromion and the humeral head was wider on the affected side by one half finger breath or more, it was judged to be subluxation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Muscle Strength, Measured by Physical Examination, Per Medical Research Council Muscle Strength Grading System
secondary_outcome.description: Muscle strength was measured for forward flexion and abduction of the shoulder per Medical Research Council (MRC) scale in each participants. Their mean +/- SD were calculated in each group. MRC scale: Grade 5: Normal and can move against full resistance. Grade 4: Reduced but can move against resistance. Grade 3: Can move only against gravity Grade 2: Can move without gravity Grade 1: Only a trace of movement Grade 0: No movement.

arm_group.description: patients with hemiplegia, without other musculoskeletal disorders of the shoulder

study_pop.textblock: university hospital, department of rehabilitation medicine admitted patients due to hemiplegia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- hemiplegia; unilateral weakness of sudden onset
- secondary to strokes or other brain lesions
- compatible with brain lesions confirmed by imaging studies
Exclusion Criteria:
- bilateral weakness
- any history of intensive trauma of the shoulder, reported
- preexisting musculoskeletal disorder of the shoulder

overall_official.affiliation: Seoul National University College of Medicine

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment period: Jan, 2008 - Dec, 2009 Recruitment site: Seoul National University Eligible canditates from: inpatients in the department of rehabilitation medicine of the hospital Methods of recruitment: research physicians informed about the study to all eligible candidates and asked if they agreed to participate.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: The study was designed to recruit hemiplegic patients of diverse degree of paresis with the same size. Because the crude distribution of the motor weakness was not even, the recruitment process adjusted the distribution of the severity of paresis, by recruiting patients of different motor strength in a consecutive way.

group.title: Hemiplegia
group.description: patients with hemiplegia, without other musculoskeletal disorders of the shoulder

participants_list.participants: >=10 for each muscle strength per MRC scale, after excluding the cases following exclusion criteria

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
